 MOLDOVA FIRST PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJECT Loan and Project Summary Borrower: Republic of Moldova Beneficiary: Ministry of Finance (MOF), National Bank of Moldova (NBM), Ministry of Economy (MOE), participating financial intermediaries (PFIs), and private enterprises. Poverty Category: N/A Amount: US$25 million equivalent and DEM14 million equivalent (about US$10 million). Terms: A single currency loan repayable over twenty years, including a five year grace period and in two tranches: a US dollar tranche in an amount of US$25 million and a deutsche mark tranche in an amount of DEM14 million equivalent at the Bank's standard US dollar and DEM Libor-based rates, respectively. Onlending Terms: Bank funds under the credit component will be onlent by the MOF to PFIs in US dollars or deutsche marks; from the PFIs to final borrowers in the same currency at freely determined interest rates. The cost to PFIs will reflect the cost of Bank funds, the administrative cost of the Technical Unit (TU) in the MOF, part of administrative costs of the Project Implementation Unit (PIU), and a premium to cover the credit risk associated with the PFIs. Depending on subproject requirements, the maturity of subloans granted to finance capital formation would vary from 1 to 5 years; working capital subloans would be for a maximum of 18 months. Objectives: The principal objective of the project is to support and help accelerate the Government's reform program in the enterprise and financial sectors, focusing especially on measures enhancing the links between commercial banks and enterprises. In particular, the project will: (a) accelerate the emergence and growth of small- and medium-scale enterprises (SMEs); (b) streamline larger enterprises and release assets into the market, thus creating smaller, focused companies; and (c) increase the efficiency of resource mobilization and credit allocation through the provision of assistance to restructure the banking system, strengthen the infrastructure for banking activity, and provide institutional development support for solvent banks. Description: The Project comprises two components: an enterprise sector strengthening component and a financial sector strengthening component. The enterprise sector strengthening component would support enterprise adjustment by providing post- privatization assistance, through a new Enterprise Assistance Agency (EAA), to selected large enterprises and would finance the automation of the Tax Administration in the MOF. Thefinancial sector strengthening component would
 ii provide resources, through qualified participating banks, for medium-term loans to private and privatized enterprises. This component would also assist in the development of banking skills in the PFIs, the automation of the NBM, and the further development of the payments system. Benefits: Anticipated benefits of the proposed project are: (a) strengthening the supply response to the Government's reform program through the introduction of a comprehensive program of support for the development of SMEs and the turnaround of troubled enterprises; (b) strengthening the financial infrastructure by upgrading the payments system, automating the Tax Administration and the NBM; (c) improving the quality of banks by strengthening the regulatory and supervisory environment in which banks operate; and (d) enabling privatized and new private enterprises to obtain financing at competitive rates for investments. Risks: Risks include: (a) increasing pressure on the Government to reverse the reform measures if and to the extent that the lack of supply response continues-dealing with this risk is the fundamental purpose of this operation; (b) possible backsliding by the Government that will lead to (i) the SCC not sending enterprises into bankruptcy that cannot be restructured successfully under the EAA, and (ii) future budgetary contributions being made to enterprises under EAA's care; (c) institutional weakness of the NBM and PFIs which would lead to a slow disbursement of the credit component-technical assistance has been incorporated into the project design specifically to address this risk; (d) afurther deterioration of the econonty could lead to a significant build-up of non-performing loans which would have a debilitating effect on the already weak financial sector; and (e) slow disbursement of the credit line due to possible competition from directed subsidized credits that might be reintroduced for political reasons. This risk is addressed through an agreement with the Government that a significant part of funds from the budget (earmarked for private enterprise assistance) be channeled through the project-supported TU on market terms.  I. BACKGROUND A. Country Context 1.1 Moldova is a landlocked country situated between Romania and Ukraine, with a territory of 33,700 square kilometers. It became independent on August 27, 1991. With a population of 4.3 million, Moldova is the most densely populated country of the former Soviet Union (FSU). The population is 67 percent ethnic Moldovan, 14 percent Ukrainian, 13 percent Russian, 4 percent Gagauz (a Christian Turkish people), and 2 percent Bulgarian. 1.2 During Moldova's transition to independence, intense conflict arose due to ethnic factors and differences in approach to economic reform and restructuring. The armed conflict, which ended in a cease fire in July 1992, resulted in the de facto partition of the country, with the Transnistria region remaining under separate control. A new Government took over after the parliamentary election in February 1994 and the Parliament adopted a new Constitution, which establishes a framework for recognizing ethnic differences and provides democratic mechanisms for solving conflicts. The population decided by referendum in March 1994 that the country would remain independent of its powerful neighbors. This decision lowered tensions in Transnistria's relations with the rest of the country. Moldova's efforts to reduce the risk of conflict through peaceful and constitutionally-based negotiations as well as through rebuilding economic relations have so far been productive. Moldova has entered into trade agreements with the CIS and a number of countries, including Romania and Germany. 1.3 Moldova's rich soil and moderate climate are advantageous for agricultural production. During the Soviet period, Moldova developed as a producer of raw and processed foodstuffs (primarily grapes, grains, wines, fruit, vegetables and livestock). Agriculture (about 40%) and the agro-processing industry (about 20%) accounted for most of the National Material Product (NMP) while the industrial sector (household appliances, wood processing, high technology electrical goods and inputs for defense industries) accounted for an additional 20 percent of NMP. 1.4 The Soviet economy was designed as a centrally-planned production line spreading over eleven time zones, in which Moldovan enterprises played a fully integrated role. Most large industries in Moldova were controlled from Moscow. As a result, Moldova was, and still is highly interdependent with other FSU economies. Its small, open economy has therefore been extremely vulnerable to the disruption of trade and payments as well as falling demand for its traditional products that has followed the disintegration of the FSU. In addition, Moldova has suffered a series of climatic disasters that have reinforced the sharp fall in GDP, now at an estimated 40 percent of its level in 1990. B. Stabilization and Structural Reform 1.5 Stabilization. Moldova suffered one of the largest terms of trade shocks of any FSU country. Its dependence on imported energy, and the movement of energy prices to market levels, have lowered real incomes and created an external balance of payments deficit which continues to pose financing problems. Foreign exchange reserves, as of November 1995, were estimated at over four months of imports. Moldova's position as a small member of the ruble area meant that its role in determining domestic monetary policy in the early years of the transition was essentially passive. Inflation approached 2,000 percent in 1992. In November 1993, the NBM officially introduced the new national currency, the leu, supported by firm financial policies, including a ceiling on credit to Government. Over eighty percent of credit is now made available through refinancing auctions; almost all remaining credit is offered at the auction-determined monthly interest rate. Inflation has been reduced from monthly rates of 30-40 percent for most of 1993 to 1.0 percent in the third quarter of 1995. The interest rate on loans peaked at 31 percent per month in early 1
 1994, and then followed inflation down to eventually reach about 4 percent in November 1994. The central bank auction rate was 1.7 percent per month in October 1995. Commercial interest rates are, however, much higher, at about 5 percent per month on average, but these too are on a downward trend. Fiscal tightening reinforced monetary firmness during 1993 and early 1994. Budget transfers to enterprises were cut to about one percent of public expenditures in 1993, from 21 percent in 1992, and the largest consumer subsidies, on bread and milk prices, were eliminated in May 1994. The fiscal deficit was narrowed from over 23 percent of GDP in 1992 to 8 percent in 1994, and is expected to be 4 percent in 1995. 1.6 Structural Reform. As early as 1990 the Government took the first steps towards the creation of a market economy. However, progress was hampered by divergences between Government and Parliament on the course of reform and the inertia associated with centrally planned practices and expectations. Significant change began in March 1993, when Parliament adopted the Government's Action Program for the stabilization and recovery of the economy, supported by the IMF and the World Bank. Structural reforms began in earnest, with substantial liberalization of trade and prices, the abolition of preferential credit, and initial steps to reform agricultural policies and improve social protection. 1.7 The new Government which took office in March 1994 has deepened structural reforms. In the financial sector, it is committed to promoting the development of a modem commercial banking system overseen by an autonomous central bank. The NBM has started to build the regulatory and supervisory framework to improve the safety and soundness of the banking system and is committed to a thorough restructuring of the sector. The NBM is beginning to extend its scope of responsibility and competence from the conduct of monetary policy into other central banking areas by tightening prudential regulations, and by introducing loan classification and provisioning requirements. A new Banking Law adopted by Parliament in July 1995 strengthened the NBM's powers of supervision and enforcement of safety standards in commercial banks. The former branches of the Soviet specialized banks were turned into Moldovan state banks before being nominally privatized. More than 20 new private banks have entered the system. 1.8 Parliament approved the Privatization Law in July 1991, but implementation was delayed, initially by the outbreak of conflict over the status of Transnistria and continuing debate on methods of privatization. Significant progress was made from June 1994 onwards, although there is still resistance to small-scale privatization from local authorities and line Ministries. As of end of June 1995, 741 medium- and large-scale enterprises had been auctioned and 563 small-scale objects had been privatized through public auctions. The Government intends to transfer roughly 80 percent of state assets, which includes the large majority of productive enterprises, into private forms of ownership. 1.9 The Government is delivering a strong signal on payments discipline through initiation of a program of enterprise restructuring, with pilot liquidations of several loss-makers. The Government has made significant progress towards creating a supportive business environment by removing all export restrictions. All price and margin controls have been removed-with the exception of a short list of socially sensitive goods from which margin controls will be removed by end-1995-and the maximum tariff is being reduced in stages to 20 percent by December 31, 1995. The Government has removed all export taxes and has started with the implementation of a more rational tax structure, through the introduction of a new corporate profit tax, excise taxes and VAT. 1.10 Competition in the agricultural sector is being enhanced by the dismantling of the large parastatals which dominated grain procurement and agricultural input supply and by the audit and reorganization of Moldcoop, the cooperative which controls rural retail trade. 1.11 Pensions and other benefits have been de-linked from the minimum wage, and benefits will be increased through targeted, flat-rate cost-of-living adjustments within the limits set by the overall fiscal stance. 2
 The pension age is to be raised and the Government has agreed to take over severance pay obligations of liquidated enterprises to assist enterprise adjustment and provide for displaced workers. C. Relations with the International Financial Institutions 1.12 Moldova became a member of the World Bank in August 1992. The first Bank loan to the country, the Emergency Drought Recovery Loan (3569-MD) of US$26 million, was approved by the Board on October 21, 1993, with the objective of financing critically needed agricultural imports after the severe drought of 1992. The IMF supported the Government's stabilization efforts through a Compensatory and Contingency Financing Facility-CCFF (March 1993); a Systemic Transformation Facility in September 1993; and a Stand-by arrangement (approved in December 1993). In October 1993 the Bank extended a second loan to Moldova, the Rehabilitation Loan (3653-MD) of US$60 million, to support the initial stage of structural reform and finance critically needed imports such as oil and gas. The Structural Adjustment Loan-SAL (3815-MD), also of US$60 million, was approved on December 8, 1994, and is designed to deepen the stability and reform efforts and support the Government budget. The second tranche of the SAL was released in October 1995. The IMF granted a second CCFF in December 1994 and approved a second Stand-by in March 1995. The Pre-Export Guarantee Facility (3851-MD) of US$30 million, effective since October 1995, has the objective of stimulating viable production for export and building bridges with foreign financiers, traders, and ultimately investors by mitigating the risk of changes in the policy environment. D. Project Background 1.13 The Bank has supported structural reforms which have resulted in trade and price liberalization, the development by the NBM of the functions appropriate to a central bank, and a substantial shift in ownership from the public to the private sector. Other donors are supporting the implementation of complementary reforms which will enhance the prospects of this project's success. The US Government is giving substantial support to the privatization process and the development of capital markets. Other donors are assisting with the development of the legal framework for business, formulation of the public investment program, review of social sector programs, and numerous programs in the agriculture sector. The emphasis of the Bank's own operations is now shifting from support for the policy framework necessary for the transition to a market economy towards the promotion of adjustment in the economy. Bank operations being prepared in parallel in the agriculture and energy sectors will address constraints to supply response in those sectors. The proposed project will build on and consolidate existing policy reforms in the enterprise and financial sectors by continuing the dialogue and providing the institutional development and incentives needed to make those reforms effective. 1.14 To allow the economy to recover, resources will need to be freed from the old economic structures and channeled through market mechanisms to help fuel new private sector growth. A disproportionate share of credit available in the economy is absorbed by old, inefficient industries, which also hold a major share of assets and commercial space, crowding out the nascent private sector. The proposed project aims to help free these resources and facilitate the emergence of market-based links between enterprises and banks, thus promoting private sector investment and growth. The project is composed of mutually- reinforcing components designed to foster new business development, promote privatization and rationalization of the old industrial and agro-processing enterprises, and provide incentives for efficient resource allocation through the supply of credit on market criteria to private and privatized enterprises. 3

Issues in the Enterprise Sector 2.10 The major issue affecting the transition of the industrial sector to market-based behavior is insufficient adjustment at the enterprise level. This lack of adjustment is primarily due to a complex set of interdependent infrastructural, institutional, and capability deficiencies: * In the infrastructure area these include: an inadequate accounting system; an inherited enterprise sector structure with excessive labor and capital resources concentrated in medium and large enterprises; narrow, yet high volume product range (with the local market occupying only a fraction of installed capacity); and excessive dependence on imports. * On the institutional side, in addition to deficient laws-relating for instance to collateral and bankruptcy-and a weak commercial court system, the main obstacle to enterprise adjustment is the interlocked non-market relationship between the Government, enterprises and the former state banks which preserves the command economy approach to economic activity. - In the capabilities area the major constraint remains an overall lack of market oriented management skills-including lack of skills to prepare "bankable" projects for financing. 2.11 The above deficiencies all contribute to low competitiveness. Reluctance to privatize SMEs immediately and support the entry of private SMEs (both through spin-offs of larger SOEs as well as establishment of new SMEs) has only aggravated the current structural weaknesses and insufficient competitiveness. The interlocking relationships noted above are making the enforcement of rmancial discipline difficult. The negative impact of these problems is magnified by demonetization of the economy and a shortage of medium- and long-term finance-even for the most promising of exporters. While the above are characteristic of other small former republics of the FSU, Moldovan conditions are more severe due to a less advantageous geographical position, weaker traditional links with European economies, and a reluctance of foreign investors to invest-in part due to the unresolved political situation in Transnistria. Low Competitiveness 2.12 Enterprises aiming to shift to more competitive markets encounter major problems. The organization of production has been such that existing companies have little, if any, process or product flexibility. Most Moldovan industrial enterprises perform poorly at present according to common performance indicators. The result is low working capital productivity, high energy dependence, and very high costs. Improved production methods demand close consultation with the customer and good relationships with a range of complementary enterprises. All too often, the lack of orders has contributed to the preservation of production systems that lack the design, engineering, and organizational capabilities to succeed in a market economy. Instead, the production system combines the low productivity of short runs with the lack of flexibility of batch production systems. Product flexibility is very limited due to a severe lack of industrial design capacity. Consumer goods enterprises are facing a decline in sales due to declining purchasing power in the FSU and increased 7
 competition from firms outside the FSU. The firms visited during project preparation have been trying to compete by lowering prices but are finding this difficult due to the need to allocate large overheads across a low volume of output. Even if these enterprises were able to lower significantly the costs of production, it is unlikely that, with their present quality and design, they could increase market share. 2.13 Managerial skills required to address the deficiencies and achieve the necessary restructuring are scarce and there is a lack of determination to manage the adjustment process through radical changes in operations, methods, and structure. Managers of already privatized companies-lacking basic business skills-remain driven by volumes of production and see restructuring as contingent on: (a) the purchase of new equipment; (b) the reintroduction of soft long-term financing; and (c) the renegotiation of preferential trade agreements with FSU countries. Substantial managerial energy is spent on pressuring the Government to secure the above-even after the firms are privatized-thus putting pressure on the Government to soften hard budget constraints. 2.14 Lack of adjustment is also heavily related to inadequate accounting systems and weak motivation to change them. Accounting and financial statements are still oriented outward to feed "the center" with window-dressed historical data rather than inward, to support managers in their decision- making process (see Box 2). Financial Sector Status 2.26 Banking Structure. As of July 1, 1995 there were 22 commercial banks in Moldova: four large, former state commercial banks, 17 new local, mainly privately owned banks, and one Romanian bank. The banking sector is dominated by the four former state banks, the Social Bank, Moldindconbank, the Savings Bank, and Agroindbank, jointly accounting for 67 percent of the total credit in the banking system. They were created with a divested portfolio and liabilities and were established in 1991 as joint-stock commercial banks, taking over the activities of Moldovan branches of specialized FSU banks. The Social Bank focuses on small businesses, Moldindconbank on industry and construction, while Agroindbank specializes in the agriculture and agro-industry sector. The Savings Bank, with over 1,000 sub-branches, is the primary depository for household savings, and carries an explicit deposit guarantee from the Government. It has begun to develop as a retail lender. A core of new private banks has begun to emerge, some of which are growing very quickly in terms of both capital and assets. Seven of these banks are of significant size (Bancosind, Exim, Interprinz, Mobias, Oguz, Petrol, and Victoria) accounting for 29% of total bank credit, 35% of total regulatory capital, 21 % of total assets, and 31 % of household deposits. 2.27. Financial Condition of Banks. The four former state banks were audited in accordance with International Accounting Standards (IAS) for the period ending December 31, 1993, with a follow-up review of the June 30, 1994 loan portfolios. The objective was to determine the banks' credit condition, capital adequacy, and their overall strengths and weaknesses. The audit findings reveal a severely undercapitalized banking system: loss provisioning in three former state banks eliminated their 1993 profits and reduced their equity to negative amounts. The exception was Agroindbank, where equity remained positive but inadequate under NBM standards. Other weaknesses confirmed by the audit included: inadequate credit appraisal and monitoring as well as the absence of risk management procedures; excessive lending to shareholders and loss-making state enterprises; poor internal financial controls and outdated management information systems; lack of experienced banking staff; and excessive branch autonomy. Loan portfolio quality may have deteriorated further since the audit was completed due to further lending to loss-making enterprises, excessive bank taxation, worsening terms of trade, the further decline of trade with Russia, and recent droughts and floods. The audit showed that the four banks needed considerable strengthening. A high percentage of non- performing loans and excessive credit risk concentration appear prevalent in the system. There is inadequate provisioning for non-performing loans while the GOSBANK accounting standards fail to provide a true picture of the underlying financial health of banks. 2.28 Accounting and Auditing Framework. The international accounting firms audited the four former state banks under the IAS. The Moldovan banks, however, continue to use the GOSBANK accounting system, and have little incentive to convert. An extensive program of support and technical 12
 assistance would be required to bring Moldovan accounting standards to internationally accepted standards. The NBM has established a working committee with representatives of the commercial banks to assist in reforming the accounting practices. Banks will be required to prepare and present financial reports in compliance with Broadly Adopted Financial Statements (BAFS) format by the end of 1995. One of element of this approach includes the utilization of BAFS as a minimum reporting requirement in the transition to IAS. These efforts are now supported by TA provided by USAID. However, several of the commercial banks are already currently preparing financial statements more compatible with IAS using BAFS. Figure 4. The NBM was established by the Law of the Republic of Moldova as the central bank in 1991. The objectives of the NBM are: ensuring the stability of the national currency, issuing money, safeguarding the nation's currency reserves, implementing monetary and credit policy, and supervising the activities of the commercial banking system. The National Bank Law passed by Parliament in July 1995 refines the role of NBM and strengthens its supervision function. The operation of banks in Moldova is also governed by the Law on Financial Institutions which was passed by Parliament in July 1995. This law sets out the powers and responsibilities of the NBM regarding commercial banking activities. With the support of the IMF and the Bank, the NBM is rapidly strengthening its capacity to supervise the commercial banking system according to the provisions of the new Law. 2.30 Regulatory and Supervisory Framework. Banking supervision is addressed in both of the above laws. Although neither the regulatory nor the supervisory framework is well established, the 13
 NBM does have limited regulatory powers. These include issuance of banking licenses and supervision of commercial banks in accordance with prudential regulations. Although the NBM can exclude commercial banks which are not in compliance with its prudential standards from the credit auction, and can restrict access to securities market, these are not a practical deterrent for the four former state banks. The NBM also has the power to limit the amount of household deposits to the level of bank capital for banks which are not in compliance with prudential standards. The NBM has no right to demand or enforce a change in management of a commercial bank which is not complying with prudential standards; it only has the right to recommend to shareholders that they replace a bank's management. Nor can the NBM restrict or limit the dividends paid by commercial banks, and it can apply monetary penalties to commercial banks after agreement of the Commercial Court. 2.31 The NBM has taken several regulatory initiatives in recent years. Prudential ratios governing capital adequacy, legal lending limits, liquidity and reserves were introduced in June 1993. Supported by the Bank's SAL, allowable capital, classification and provisioning guidelines were introduced in December 1994. A new law provides for the mandatory creation of adequate reserves, encouraged by favorable tax treatment of provisioning. A bank will not be in compliance with capital regulations until the bank has evidence of adequate capital after setting aside sufficient provisions for possible loan losses. Bank licensing regulations and bank auditing guidelines have also been introduced. The NBM has adopted several additional regulatory initiatives including the introduction of risk-based capital adequacy guidelines after the banks reach solvency. Other SAL-supported regulations include: risk- weighted capital standards, reinstatement of regulations restraining insider lending to directors, officers, shareholders and related interested parties; enforcement of the limit on exposure to single borrowers of 30% of capital; and enforcement of the regulation to form an adequate allowance for loan losses. On-site supervision was introduced in the sunmmer of 1995. 2.32 Bank restructuring. As a first step in implementing a bank restructuring strategy, NBM has required all commercial banks to submit a statement of their capital position as of year-end 1994, adjusted for adequate reserves and conforming to the new Credit Classification and Provisioning Guidelines. Initial results indicate that four banks have capital deficiencies, with some banks close to insolvency. As a result, the NBM signed Memoranda of Understanding with 11 problem banks setting out measures necessary to reach a positive capital position by July 1, 1995. A comprehensive exercise assisting banks in formulating "Capital Building Programs," initiated by the Bank, is in process. All banks were advised how to prepare detailed data on their capital and financial positions as well as their strategy for the coming two years, including a forecast for growth, plans to raise capital, and problem areas that will need to be corrected to realize the strategy. Data will be analyzed by the project- supported Bank Resolution Unit (BRU) located in the NBM supervision department. BRU is assisted by USAID funded advisors. The BRU will work with problem banks to address weak points and possible restructuring or recapitalization. 2.33 Legal framework for bank operations. The legal framework relating to collateral for bank lending was established in December 1993. It has many deficiencies, however. There are, for instance, deficiencies in the registration of titles, and other property rights, and a lack of a developed commercial court system for enforcement. Financial institutions encounter difficulties in the valuation of collateral. They are not allowed to own foreclosed property and are forced to set up separate legal entities to dispose of foreclosed collateral. The new but weak secondary securities market impedes valuation of financial collateral while the Law on Securities Circulation and the Stock Exchange of May 18, 1993 (the Securities Law) covers only certain types of securities and excludes, among others, treasury bonds, bank certificates of deposits, and promissory notes. 14
 2.34 The laws on the National Bank, financial institutions and taxation of banks have been adopted by Parliament. In addition, the Securities law was amended in June 1995. A comprehensive public debt law, which also establishes the legal foundation for book-entry government securities, is expected to be passed by Parliament soon. Further, a revised law on bankruptcy was submitted to Parliament in June 1995. The court system and enforcement of existing laws, such as the laws of collateral and bankruptcy, is being strengthened. 2.35 Payments, clearing and settlement system. The bank payments system has over the last year improved in terms of the speed and efficiency of completing the payments process. Payments that used to take several weeks to clear and settle can now be completed within a week. This improvement has been facilitated in part by the adoption of an E-mail electronic delivery system which is used to deliver a range of documents. However, only six banks are connected to NBM's electronic payment system, and not all the branches of these banks are connected to the system. D. Issues in the Financial Sector 2.36 In order to support the development of the real sector of the economy it is vital that the financial sector be restructured so financial intermediation resumes. The volume of financial intermediation in relation to the size of the Moldovan economy is well below that of a Western economy of equivalent size. The Government is faced, therefore, with a number of immediate structural and infrastructural issues in the financial sector. 2.37 Banking sector structure. To the extent possible, the restructuring of the banking sector should take place in tandem with the restructuring of the enterprise sector. Without strong banks that are prepared to lend to the emerging private sector on market-based principles the effective restructuring of enterprises may not be possible. The main challenges in the banking sector at this juncture are: a) attracting capital to back new, truly commercial financial institutions; b) regaining confidence of the population in the banking system; and c) the restructuring and strengthening of commercial banks. NBM has initiated a restructuring process (see para. 2.32 above) that will entail some 11 problem banks-including three of the four large, former state banks-presenting to NBM an acceptable recapitalization plan. The Bank and the IMF are jointly working on the preparation of a restructuring strategy in support of NBM. The challenge for the NBM will be to precipitate the restructuring, merger, or liquidation of insolvent banks, but to do it in a way that will not undermine confidence in the banking system as a whole. The strong message that such a proactive approach to restructuring will inject into the banking system will create a more disciplined approach to banking operations in the system at large. The banks emerging from the restructuring process will be stronger and more able to play a central role in financial intermediation. 2.38 Bank practices. Moldova's banking sector has been nominally privatized. The four large former state banks remain, however, sensitive to pressure from the government, as well as from industrial shareholders, in making loans. This ambiguity in ownership and control undermines market discipline in granting loans. One major reason is that a significant portion of banking shares is owned by large enterprises that continue to be heavy borrowers from these banks. In addition, government pressure to make loans based on non-market criteria also adversely affect the loan portfolios. Banks still rely on the GOSBANK accounting system, which contains inconsistencies in accounting practices, clouding accurate assessment of the Banks' financial strength. However, by the end of 1995, banks will be required to prepare and present financial reports in compliance with BAFS format with full 15
 conversion to the new chart of accounts and IAS reporting required for all banks in Moldova by the end of 1996. 2.39 Skills Development. There is a need for technical assistance both in the NBM and in the commercial banks to improve a wide range of banking skills. The banks need to develop expertise, among others, in project finance structuring and analysis, risk analysis, credit initiation, credit appraisal and loan monitoring. There is also need for on-the-job assistance for commercial banks in bank strategic management, human resources development, operations, treasury management and trade finance products and services. Other weaknesses include the lack of experience in, trade finance techniques, foreign exchange trading and its risks, and internal audit and controls. USAID has begun a program to raise professional standards by training local bankers, while several banks have resident Western advisors. However, more technical assistance is requiree, to expand the professional level of the commercial bankers and NBM supervisors to reach a level competitive with their western counterparts. 2.40 Regulatory and supervisory framework. A sound regulatory framework and strong mechanism for banking supervision are vital prerequisites for a well functioning, solvent banking system. The NBM, in collaboration with the IMF and in consultation with the Bankers Association in Moldova, assisted in the drafting of the National Bank and Financial Institution Laws which have been enacted by Parliament. The Supervision Department of the NBM has increased its staff over the last few months but needs considerable reinforcement. While the NBM's capacity to understand, regulate and supervise the banking system has grown recently-reinforced by the two new laws-the supervision function needs to improve its skills in techniques of bank supervision, both on- and off-site. To support NBM's strategy for restructuring the banking sector it will be important to develop skills within the department of Banking Supervision for the resolution of problems associated with bank insolvency. 2.41 Credit Channeling Mechanism. There is a need to strengthen Moldovan banks-through tailored programs of institutional development-to a point where they are able to channel medium-term credit to private enterprises from multilateral international organizations, and other donors. In this way banks would be able to finance the new investment needed to support the economic transition. In recent years a number of new private banks have developed that are well capitalized and are lending on market-based principles. These banks, which may become the core of the banking system in due course, have the ability to absorb new skills, including those needed to channel medium-term credit. 2.42 Infrastructure Development. The infrastructure for the banking system requires significant strengthening. The introduction of internationally accepted accounting and auditing principles, for instance, would provide the necessary foundation for banks and their clients to function in a market economy. The payments system should be further upgraded if it is to support the enhanced volume of transactions expected as economic activity increases. The NBM is at the center of the payments and clearing system and it will require extensive investment in computer hardware and software to support the upgrading of that system. The legal, regulatory and supervisory framework for banks should also be upgraded by improving and implementing existing laws, especially in the field of bankruptcy, collateral, and property rights. More generally, there is a need to improve the computing and management information infrastructure in those institutions-the NBM and the Tax Authority-that interface with the banking system and the enterprise sector. 2.42 Capital Market Development. The legal framework for a well-functioning capital market should be developed to support the current acceleration in the privatization process and the resulting demand for 16
 an efficient securities trading mechanism. As the focal point for secondary market trading-the stock market-develops, the parallel development of capital market infrastructure such as a share depository, a system for clearing and settlement of shares, and a system of share registry and share ownership transfer is required. There is also a need for a Securities and Exchange Commission, or its equivalent, to safeguard the investing public's interests. Furthermore, it is imperative that adequate regulations regarding investment funds are drafted to safeguard small investors. 2.43 A formal secondary market for trading shares of privatized and private companies is taking its first steps with strong logistical support from USAID. The stock exchange-established as a joint-stock company by a group of market operators-began operations in July 1995 while the State Securities Commission (SSC) was appointed in mid-1995. Both institutions are at their nascent stage and require further institutional development and staffing to create a secure and efficient secondary market. The first priority is to create an effective supervision system for investment funds. These play a critical role in privatization and will likely play an equally important role in the corporate governance of privatized companies. The Capital Market Monitoring Unit, created under the auspices of USAID, is a valuable first step in this direction and should be accommodated by the SSC. There is also an urgent need to create a sound environment for secondary trading-reliable registrars and share depositories and a system for the clearing and settlement of securities and related payments. The SSC should also develop and implement licensing requirements for professional market operators: broker/dealers, investment advisors, portfolio managers. These requirements in turn should then lead to the development of adequate and efficient safeguards for small, unsophisticated investors who dominate the Moldovan market. 17
 III. PROJECT DESCRIPTION A. Objectives and Scope 3.1 The project is part of a broader program of support for the reform of the enterprise and financial sectors. It was conceived because of the limited supply response to date to the stabilization and structural reform measures being implemented under the Government's economic reform program. The project would be supported by a proposed World Bank loan of US$35 million equivalent, and funding from other donors, including EU (TACIS), Germany, Netherlands, and USAID, totaling US$7 million. 3.2 The principal objective of the project is to support and help accelerate the Government reform program in the enterprise and financial sectors, focusing especially on measures enhancing the links between commercial banks and enterprises. In particular, the project will: (a) accelerate the emergence and growth of SMEs; (b) streamline larger enterprises and release currently unproductive assets into the market, thus creating smaller, focused companies; (c) increase the efficiency of resource mobilization and credit allocation through the provision of assistance to restructure the banking systs -n; and (d) strengthen the infrastructure for banking activity, and provide institutional development si pk irt for solvent banks. The project will have a strong demonstration effect on the whole enterprise s -crr by showing the benefits of firm-level adjustment, and by reinforcing financial discipline through facilitating the exit of non-viable parts of enterprises and releasing their assets into the market. In the financial sector the project will increase the efficiency of resource mobilization and credit allocation through the provision of assistance to restmicture the banking system, strengthen the infrastructure for banking activity, and provide institutional development support for solvent banks. B. Project Structure 3.3 The project will comprise two components: an enterprise sector strengthening component (ESSC); and a financial sector strengthening component (FSSC). The ESSC will facilitate the growth of a population of viable and competitive enterprises by providing technical assistance (TA) for rationalizing selected larger enterprises and by providing private SMEs with the technical assistance necessary to prepare bankable investment projects. A Bank survey of SMEs indicates that taxes and tax administration are significant obstacles to private sector development. The ESSC will provide computer hardware and software to assist in strengthening the ability of the Tax Administration within the MOF to collect taxes in a timely fashion and lower transaction costs. The FSSC will provide resources-a credit line-through qualified participating banks, for medium-term loans to private and privatized enterprises. This component will also: (a) assist with the development of banking skills in the participating banks; (b) strengthen the payments system through the provision of computer software and hardware for the Clearing Center at the NBM; and (c) support further institutional development- including automation-for NBM as a whole. C. Enterprise Sector Strengthening Component 3.4 The enterprise sector strengthening component totals US$9.32 million, of which 53% would be financed by the proposed Bank loan. It consists of (a) an Enterprise Assistance Program (EAP) for US$7.4 million and (b) a Tax Administration Program (TAP) for US$1.92 million to finance the automation of the Tax Administration in the MOF. The ESSC has the following objectives: 18
 * freeing assets presently locked in large- and medium-sized enterprises and making such assets available for private SMEs while preserving the core businesses of streamlined enterprises; * stimulating decentralized, out-of-court, creditor-led action aimed at imposing financial discipline on enterprises through rehabilitation of their businesses and debt restructuring voluntarily agreed between owners and creditors; * serving as a demonstration of the positive after-effects of privatization; and * preparing bankable investment projects. 3.5 Enterprise Assistance Program. The EAP would assist the Government in the initiation of market oriented adjustment of selected enterprises through the tightening of financial discipline and the provision of supporting expertise and technical skills. Streamlining in enterprises will be achieved through the introduction of an out-of-court, creditor-led adjustment of selected enterprises, aided by an Enterprise Assistance Agency (EAA) established on June 21, 1995 (for details on the EAA see Chapter IV). 3.6 Most of the activities leading to tighter financial discipline through the implementation of the EAP would be left to a decentralized process operated by market agents including: (i) owners and management of enterprises to be restructured; and (ii) commercial (individuals, other enterprises and commercial banks) and public creditors (the State Budget, the Social Fund, energy suppliers and wages). They would be advised in this process by local and foreigrf consultants. 3.7 Only private or privatized enterprises, provided they have had a general meeting of shareholders and a Board of Directors, are eligible to participate in the EAP. 3.8 To encourage enterprises to undertake sometimes painful adjustment measures, a variety of incentives are foreseen, including the restructuring of arrears and penalties due to public creditors and commercial creditors (including banks). Furthermore, management may sell assets or divisions of the enterprise in a transparent and competitive way-within the general limits pre-approved by owners. 3.9 At the same time, enterprises entering the EAP are restricted in their access to external financing for the duration of the agreed moratorium. D. Financial Sector Strengthening Component 3.17 The objectives of this component are fourfold. The first is to provide medium-term financing for newly privatized and other private sector enterprises. The second is to establish a robust channel for credit lines in the context of a strengthened regulatory and supervisory environment for banks. The third objective is to provide an incentive for participating banks to strengthen themselves to become core banks in the Moldovan banking system. The final objective is to support the institutional development of those parts of the NBM that interface closely with the private banking system. 3.18 The FSSC consists of the following sub-components: (i) financial support for the Credit Program, including an SME window; (ii) institutional strengthening and technical support for the TU, 21

Potential PFIs would have to be individually appraised by the TU and be satisfactory to the Bank. A precondition for any bank to become eligible would be to have its financial statements audited by external auditors acceptable to the Bank. The evaluation of a PFI would focus on five main areas: (i) capital adequacy, (ii) asset quality, (iii) management effectiveness, (iv) earnings performance, and (v) liquidity. The specific eligibility criteria were confirmed at negotiations (see Annex B). As a condition of loan effectiveness, two Subsidiary Loan Agreements satisfactory to the Bank must have been signed. While the banking sector of Moldova is in need of serious restructuring, at least one large and two smaller banks are expected to meet the eligibility criteria immediately. Temporary deviations from the eligibility criteria could be allowed as long as the SLA to be entered into between the TU and PFI includes a custom-made program of recapitalization and/or institutional development. Such programs would include a negotiated timetable for implementation, and could be supported by the technical assistance sub-component for the banking system. 3.20 The demand for medium-term credit. As Moldova's economy stabilizes, privatized enterprises and new entrepreneurs will require access to medium-term financing to support the investment needed to restructure the economy. In the context of a Bank survey of SMEs, virtually all entrepreneurs (92%) cited the lack of longer-term financing as a constraint on their operations, and expressed interest in drawing on the proposed line of credit. However, the investment needs of the restructured larger enterprises may, in addition, boost the demand estimate. Accordingly, the US$27 million credit line should be adequately sized to meet a significant proportion of demand in the project pipeline, taking into account the limited availability of foreign exchange facilities in Moldova. The binding constraint in defining the size of the credit component has been the estimated absorptive capacity of the banks- -i.e., their ability to channel additional loan funds without violating prudential regulations. The regulatory capital of the banksI determines the additional funds banks can channel. The NBM's prudential regulations limit the maximum loan size to a single borrower to 30% of this regulatory capital. However, some banks-the initial focus of the proposed credit line-have had success in issuing new shares. Experience in other FSU countries shows that bank capital has the potential to grow quite quickly in some instances. See Box 4. Economic Analysis and Rationale for Bank Involvement 3.29 Policy Environment. Moldova is one of the most disciplined and successful countries of the FSU in introducing and maintaining severe macroeconomic stabilization measures. Its budget deficit has been reduced to 4.0% of GDP in 1995 while the annual inflation rate is below 10%. Stabilization of the domestic currency vis-a-vis the US dollar has substantially increased the transparency of enterprise activities in the industrial sector as well as their competitiveness in domestic and foreign markets. Export taxes and quantitative import restrictions have been removed, and the maximum import tariff reduced to 20%. Budget subsidies to the industrial sector have been limited to relatively insignificant levels and their procedures have become more transparent. 3.30 Price distortions have been largely eliminated. Interest rates are determined at auction; over eighty percent of credit is made available through refinancing auctions and the remaining credit is offered at the auction-determined monthly interest rate. The exchange rate has been unified and foreign exchange is purchased at regular inter-bank auctions. Commodity prices in both domestic and foreign trade have been liberalized with only a very few exceptions (due to be removed in December 1995). Consequently, the risk of a downward shift in rates of return on particular projects due to the removal of policy related advantages is low. 3.31 Core Economic Objective. The main objective of the project is to shift enterprise adjustment and credit allocation decisions to market forces. The fast pace of privatization, with an exclusive use of the mass privatization approach, has left behind unsolved problems. These include an excessive concentration of resources in existing, mostly inefficient and uneconomic industrial structures and the continued operation of the remnants of a collapsed central planning system. The purpose of the Project is to jump-start the country's emergence from this growih-inhibiting and market-hostile situation. This will be done by providing a balance of incentives and penalties together with the required information and expertise to assist market participants to make good economic and financial decisions and create a self-sustaining market process. To achieve this objective, the Project will build the institutional and 25
 regulatory capacity to carry out creditor-led restructuring, free assets, and create financing opportunities. 3.32 Achievement of Core Economic Objective. The proposed creditor-led restructuring of privatized enterprises is designed to free assets to help increase the number of small enterprises (the supply side). Publicly sponsored promotion, including an SME small-banking loan window, will support the small enterprise sector, building on approaches used successfully in Poland and Russia. The need to increase financing opportunities available to SMEs is addressed in a twofold way: strengthening commercial banks in their capacity to lend and making technical assistance available to emerging private businesses to prepare bankable projects. At present, commercial banks are not only short of resources to lend, they also have difficulty in articulating their long-term lending policy and in assessing the available lending projects. The lack of these capacities in the banks often results in (i) excessively risky lending to projects promising unrealistically high rates of re-turn (mostly in trade) or (ii) offering "rescue lending" to selected enterprises with little concern about the enterprise's or the bank's future-at the expense of sound projects in manufacturing and services. 3.33 The Project has already had a visible impact on policy-establishing new relations between the Government and enterprises through a newly created conimittee of public creditors and the promotion of a non-governmental agency supporting enterprise efforts to become more competitive and market oriented. By facilitating the streamlining and downsizing, opening the channel for asset sales, introducing voluntary liquidations and supporting leaner bankruptcy procedures, the Project builds a strong base for the growth of new, smaller and better focused enterprises and has increased the demand for credit for bankable projects, part of which would be met by the proposed PSD credit line component. 3.34 Institutional Capacity and Regulatory Framework. The Project has initiated and is supporting a network of non-governmental institutions and related supporting activities: the EAA, business centers, consulting firms oriented to small and medium enterprises, and training programs for the enterprise and banking sectors. In addition, the judicial system is being strengthened in its capacity to deal with commercial cases (bankruptcy and restructuring). The project is also supporting the development of an appropriate legal and regulations framework. 3.35 New institutions and a regulatory framework will be of little use if there are no commercial entities sufficiently motivated to use them. The proposed TA to enterprises, available through the EAA, will facilitate the process of creditor-led restructuring by decreasing the level of information asymmetry between the management of a company and its creditors -- thereby balancing the bargaining power of the two parties. Presently, managers of former state enterprises grossly overvalue the assets of their companies as well as their ability to generate positive cash flows. This is mostly due to their valuation of production capacity based on historical costs of investments in fixed capital, and too optimistic an assessment of potential markets. On the other hand, creditors are at a significant disadvantage as market verification of the assertions of managers is not available. In this case, a sound assessment of the potential gains or losses available from keeping a business going, versus liquidation (or substantial streamlining), is difficult if not impossible to determine; often the outcome is deadlock, and both sides lose. TA will lead to a narrowing of this information gap. 3.36 To accelerate the positive demonstration effects of this pilot program and increase the number of financially eligible projects, the preparatory costs of credit applications and evaluation would be supported by grant-funded TA. Such TA will also promote the development of expertise in the 26
 qualifying commercial banks to evaluate credit applications better, deal with debt restructuring, and lower the level of risk in the lending portfolio. 3.37 Fiscal Impact. The line of credit will be fully self-sustaining. Expected on-lending margins will cover the costs the Technical Unit incurs while it operates and supervises the loan disbursement, as well as the risk of a default of PFIs. In addition, the technical assistance available to enterprises will create new value-added to be allocated between both sides of a contract-the enterprise and its creditors-including the State budget. Early results from the pilot stage of the project indicate that tax revenue from participating enterprises has already risen significantly. In this sense, the budget can expect positive net fiscal results over the medium term and therefore treat the financing of TA as an investment. The state budget is usually one of the biggest creditors. Money spent on TA will be recouped by collecting overdue and current taxes, which otherwise would not be collectable. The successful implementation of the restructuring programs will result in the broadening of the tax base- through restructured companies, new businesses spun-off from downsized companies, and commercial creditors who, in many instances are currently unable to pay taxes themselves. Jobs will be generated in the core businesses of restructured companies and interrelated networks of companies, yielding additional tax revenue and limiting budgetary and quasi-budgetary severance payments and unemployment benefits. 3.38 Analysis of Alternatives. During project preparation, an in-depth analysis of four possible channels for medium- and long-term funds was undertaken. In addition to a credit line, these included the creation of a venture capital fund, a credit cooperative, and a leasing company. The research showed that the credit line was the best and most operational option at this stage; the other alternatives also generated significant benefits but required further institutional and regulatory development before the risks and costs they entailed could be well managed and reduced to reasonable levels. Specifically, the strengthening of private commercial banks to manage risk, as required to support the credit line, is the most cost-effective way of mitigating risk in the short-term while still making medium to long-tern fmance available. Once current efforts to strengthen property rights to land and fixed assets, to improve registration and to increase enforcement of collateral and bankruptcy procedures are further advanced, and the appropriate legislation has been passed, with specialists trained in the new procedures, then the ability to reduce risk and enable repossession of on-lent funds will be enhanced to the stage where the other options will become attractive. 3.39 Cost-benefit Analysis. A study of small businesses completed during project preparation, along with interviews with managers of a number of privatized enterprises, indicate that financial rates of return to the line of credit sub-projects will exceed the borrowing costs of the PFIs. Available business proposals show that existing and new ventures in manufacturing and services wouid be able to afford an annual interest rate around 16% (in US dollar terms). 3.40 On average, financial rates of return correctly reflect expected economic rates of return; there are no major distortions which could result in a systematically biased allocation of capital or in quasi- rents for some borrowers. Financial rates of return are likely to remain higher than economic rates of return because of the large number of investment opportunities in new products and services and the persistent scarcity of available capital. As foreign trade has already been liberalized, Moldovan enterprises are already facing competitive prices and will not be able to benefit from protection under the current trade regime. Growing competitiveness and openness of markets will reduce costs through: rationalization of employment and energy use, removing the inefficiencies of barter transactions, shortening investment cycles, and improving the quality and availability of information. 27
 3.41 Analysis of the sensitivity of the estimated rates of return to possible policy changes and sovereign risks can only be tentative. However, the continuing progress in improving the policy environment and implementing strict macroeconomic measures, and the growing geopolitical stabilization, strongly indicate that the number of opportunities for profitable business will grow. The proposed line of credit can easily be topped up if it proves successful. 3.42 The project is expected to generate substantial positive externalities through its demonstration effects, and by increasing the demand for credit (the number of potentially bankable projects prepared in the rapidly growing private sector) and matching it with an efficient supply of credit (the number of PFIs graduating from the Bank's rehabilitation program and approving sub-loans solely on the basis of market criteria). While the total value of the project is relatively small in relation to the overall investment needs of the economy, it is expected these demonstration effects will accelerate the mobilization of investor interests through follow-up credits and investments into more competitive and better, structurally-adjusted enterprise and banking sectors. 3.43 Rationale for Bank Involvement. The Bank is committed to assist Moldova in pursuing its program of economic reforms and its efforts to launch a sustainable economic recovery. Notwithstanding the introduction of macro-stabilization and significant structural reforms, the response of the enterprise and financial sectors has been slow. Given the central role these two sectors will play in transforming the economy in the direction of positive growth, it is now vital to focus efforts on their simultaneous restructuring. 3.44 In the enterprise sector, the Bank is supporting the Government in its efforts to increase the role of the private sector, both through the acceleration of the privatization process and by facilitating the development and growth of new private firms. In the context of the recent SAL, the Bank supported the Government in its efforts to create a competitive environment and tighten financial discipline throughout the economy, thus inducing faster adjustment at the enterprise level. The pilot liquidation of seven SOEs has helped the private sector gain access to unused state assets and has sent a strong signal through the enterprise sector about the Govermnent's resolve to enforce a hard budget constraint. The Government's degree of May 15, 1995 on "Critical Measures for Improving the Financial-Economic Standing of Industrial Enterprises," drafted with the Bank's support during project preparation, introduces a decentralized, creditor-led debt reconciliation and restructuring program. The Bank is supporting, also through project preparation, the development of SMEs by removing constraints that have impeded their growth and by mobilizing grant resources to finance the acquisition of key business skills. 3.45 In the financial sector, the Bank has had a continuing dialogue with the NBM, the financial institutions and the Governrment. The Bank is providing assistance in developing a restructuring strategy for the Moldovan banking sector. The objective is to develop a robust financial system that can effectively mobilize domestic and foreign resources and on-lend them to viable enterprises. The Bank is working very closely with the IMF on issues of financial sector strategy in Moldova. A common approach is being adopted on the key reform issues which is having a powerful positive influence on the NBM. The proposed project would also enhance the scope for using the Pre-Export Guarantee Facility, as local banks' capacity would be developed allowing them to assume their normal role in working capital financing. 28
 3.46 The Bank has played the leading role in coordinating major donors involved in post- privatization restructuring of the economy. It is the only institution currently active in Moldova which is able to maintain a policy debate with the Government on essential framework reforms across differing sectors while also orchestrating specific technical interventions designed to support the reform process in practical ways. 3.47 The Bank's Country Assistance Strategy envisions that the primary impetus to growth will come from unleashing the private sector. The proposed project, with its emphasis on creating a supportive policy environment and through its support of simultaneous restructuring of the enterprise and financial sectors, will play a major role in stimulating the private sector. 3.48 This project is not intended to have a poverty focus, nor is it expected to have any negative environmental effects. Implementation Arrangements 4.1 The Executing Agency for the Borrower (the Republic of Moldova) would be the MOF, within which there would be a Project Implementation Unit (PIU) responsible for overseeing and coordinating the implementation of the two components of the Project. The PIU would coordinate with the governrnent entities in charge of each component of the Project. Enterprise Sector Strengthening Component 4.2 Enterprise Assistance Program (EAP). The credit line would be managed by a TU established at the NBM. The NBM would act only as a fiscal agent and would not take any of the credit risks involved in the intermediation of funds to the private sector. The role of the NBM in the intermediation of the credit line would be defined in a Fiscal Agency Agreement to be entered into between the Government and the NBM. The TU would channel funds to participating financial intermediaries, which would on-lend the credit line resources to their private sector clients. Credit line resources would be available from two sources: (i) US$27.45 million equivalent from the 20-year maturity Bank loan, and (ii) a Government-funded Leu co-financing facility of up to US$5 million equivalent, to be funded by allotments in the National Budget over a three-year period. These sources were confirmed at negotiations. Also, a Fiscal Agency Agreement, satisfactory to the Bank, would have to be signed as a condition of loan effectiveness. 4.9 The Technical Unit. The TU would be a newly-created Apex within the NBM, under the direction of an NBM official with a solid academic background and preferably with practical lending 33
 experience. Its purpose would be to manage the credit line of the proposed Project. The TU would have four main functions: (i) the selection of participating banks and the monitoring of their continued eligibility for the intermediation of the credit line resources; (ii) the development and implementation of the credit line regulations, including on-going supervision of their compliance by PFIs and final borrowers; (iii) the day-to-day management of, and access to, the credit line by PFIs for onlending to final borrowers; and (iv) the management of the TA needed to develop in Moldovan banks the skills required for lending to private investment projects. Decisions by the TU would be made following a two-step approach. The director of the TU, in charge of the day-to-day affairs, would make formal recommnendations to the TU Committee, which would include representatives of the MOF and the MOE, in addition to the NBM. The TU's work would be guided by two basic documents each of which must be acceptable to the Bank: (i) the Operational Procedures of the TU, and (ii) the Credit Line Regulations Manual (CLRM). The organizational chart for the TU, already agreed with the Moldovan Authorities, is shown in Chart 1. Two Western banking experts would be recruited to staff the senior technical positions reporting to the director. A preliminary version of the Statutes of the TU were discussed with the authorities at the MOF and the NBM during appraisal. 4.10 In order to cover Chart 2: Organizational Chart of the Technical Unit its operational costs, the TU would be allowed to charge a fee which TU Committee would be part of the (six members representing MoF, MoE & NBM) lending rate charged to a PFI for subsidiary loans.
