The PA would have the dual purpose of receiving deposits-originating in withdrawals from the Bank loan and the servicing of subsidiary loans by PFIs-and making disbursements that would go to the servicing of the Bank loan by the Republic, the granting of subsidiary loans to PFIs, or covering the costs of operating the credit line. Besides being a depository account for liquid balances, the PA would serve the purpose of keeping full and detailed accounting of the transactions being financed out of the proceeds of the credit line. 4.12 Access to Credit Line Resources by a PFI. To access these financial resources, a PFI that has entered into a Subsidiary Loan Agreement would be able to request from the TU a commitment of credit line funds for a specified period of time, up to 4 years, which could be extended by the TU once 34
 the PFI has demonstrated a capacity to engage in successful term lending. In general, such commitments would be contingent on the PFIs ability to remain eligible for credit line use throughout the commitment period. Initial commitmnents would be for a lump-sum of US$1 million equivalent per PFI, with future increments of up to US$3 million. However, a PFI would be able to secure additional commitments only after it has itself committed no less than US$500,000 in eligible subloans (properly documented according to the CLRM). has completed an agreed trial period and is in full compliance with the performance criteria agreed upon with the TU in the Subsidiary Loan Agreement. Prior to committing additional funds from the credit line to a PFI, the TU would have to seek the consent of the Bank. 4.13 The TU would stand ready to authorize subsidiary loans financed with the Bank loan in US dollars or deutsche mark for onlending in the same currency to eligible subborrowers. The TU would also be able to offer financing in Moldovan lei from the co-financing facility to be made available through Governmental budgetary appropriations. The US dollar and deutsche mark subloans would have to go to subborrowers that have revenues in the same currencies or have other ways of hedging the foreign exchange exposure associated with a liability denominated in hard currency. Debt servicing by PFIs and subborrowers would always be in the same currency in which the loan was originally denominated. 4.14 Each subloan would be documented by a Subloan Agreement to be entered into between a PFI and its subborrower. This agreement would include a tentative disbursement schedule for the subloan and the conditions agreed for disbursement. The minimum requirements to be included in every Subloan Agreement would be listed in the Subsidiary Loan Agreement to be entered into between the TU and each PFI. 4.15 The Credit Authorization Process. The credit risk associated with a specific subloan would rest entirely with the PFI granting such credit. Thus, neither the Bank nor the TU are expected to duplicate the credit or project analysis done by the PFI. Rather, the role of the TU would be to concentrate on performing ex-post quality control reviews to determine whether credit regulations have been met by the PFI granting the subloan. This notwithstanding, the TU would hlave the flexibility to conduct ex-ante reviews of subloan documentation in those cases when a specific PFI establishes a record of non-compliance with credit regulations. Also, there would be an ex-ante review of subloan documentation when a given subloan is above a specified free-limit level and for the first two subloans granted by a PFI just starting to operate with the credit line. 4.16 Eligibility of Subborrowers and Subprojects. The proposed credit line is geared to offer medium-term financing (one- to five-year maturities for capital investments and up to 18 months for working capital) for a wide range of private investment activities in Moldova. A corporate borrower is private if more than 50 % of its ownership is in private hands. Newly privatized and other emerging private sector enterprises would be able to obtain subloans from PFIs to finance their fixed capital needs and working capital requirements. Since the credit line would be non-sector specific, subproject eligibility would be based entirely on its technical, financial, economic and enviromnental soundness. Minimum eligibility requirements for subloans, based on subproject and subborrower eligibility, would be defined in the CLRM. PFIs would be required to appraise project risks, including an evaluation that the currency of onlending is appropriate for the subborrower. This last evaluation criterion is likely to make the credit line better suited and particularly relevant for the financing of export-oriented projects. Since the credit risk associated with a subloan is taken by the PFI granting the credit, the final decision 35
 on the credit risks to be assumed, and the subloans to be granted, would be made entirely by the PFIs, following its own credit screening criteria. The minimum subloan size would be the equivalent of US$30,000 for investment projects and US$10,000 for working capital lending. The aggregate maximum subloans outstanding to any individual subborrower would be the equivalent of US$2.5 million-whether they are granted by one or more PFIs. 4.17 The SME window. At least two of the PFIs are expected to apply and participate in the intermediation of credit line resources through the so-called SME window. Lending to these subborrowers would follow the guidelines contained in the CLRM, with no differential treatment for this sub-set, save for the fact that the maximum amount of subloans per subborrower would be US$100,000, with no minimum subloan size. In order to secure adequate credit practices on the part of PFIs engaged in SME lending, the Project contemplates a special program of technical assistance geared to providing in-house western banking expertise to two of the PFIs involved with SME lending-to be financed by foreign grants to be provided directly to the selected banks. Other PFIs wishing to access the window would have to provide strong evidence to the TU-satisfactory to the Bank-that they have the outside support or in-house knowledge required to implement a facility able to provide small scale loans customized to SMEs. Furthernore, the TU would make separate credit line commitments, in tranches of US$500,000, to those PFIs eligible for this kind of lending. These commitments would be in addition to any others that the TU would normally grant to a PFI. 4.18 Eligible expenditures. In addition to financing investments in plant and equipment and working capital, the PFI would be able to finance the cost of patents, licenses, and franchises needed for the subproject's production process. Bank funds would not be used to refinance already existing subborrowers' liabilities. 4.19 Interest rates on subsidiary loans. At present there is an absence of medium-term funding for banks in the Moldovan market, given that deposits are scarce and practically all short-term. Thus, there are no useful market indicators that could be used for guidance when trying to determine a market rate at which Bank funding could be onlent to PFIs. Short-term interest rates are volatile, so they also are of little help when trying to determine an appropriate level for a sustainable medium-term rate for investment project financing. Faced with this dilemrna, the Government would like to avoid setting credit line interest rates to PFIs in an arbitrary fashion, which could result in a misallocation of resources or subsidies on the rate. As a second best option, they would be willing to charge PFIs a rate that captures the cost of funds for the Government. In the case of Bank provided resources, it has been agreed that the cost of funds would include the following components in addition to the IBRD lending rate: (i) the cost of supervising the credit line subcomponent by the MOF; (ii) the cost of setting up and operating the TU and the cost of other services to be provided by the NBM; and (iii) the cost of establishing a credit risk fund to insure the Republic against potential losses that could result from poor servicing of the credit line by some PFIs. These three costs would be incorporated in a spread over the Bank rate which would be fixed once a subsidiary loan is granted. However, in order to reflect changes in the relevant Bank lending rate, the interest rates charged on future subsidiary loans would be reviewed semi-annually. Changes in the value of any of the components of the spread would require the consent of the Bank. The detailed formula to determine the interest rate to be charged on subsidiary loans would be included in the CLRM. As the number of PFIs increases, consideration will be given to establishing a bidding mechanism for pricing subsidiary loans and allocating credit line resources among competing PFIs. The interest rate to be charged to PFIs on the counterpart funds in local currency to be made available by the Government through the TU will never be lower than that 36
 charged on US dollar funding originating from the Bank loan. Actual Leu rates will be set from time to time by the TU based on an assessment of the cost to the Government of funds raised in the local market. Prior to their implementation, all interest rates to be charged by the TU will be reviewed by the Bank. 4.20 Interest Rates on Subloans. The interest rate on subloans would be negotiated freely between each PFI and its client, taking into account market conditions and the risks involved. Every effort would be made by the TU to create transparency in the rate setting process. The formula used to calculate the rate would be incorporated into each Subloan Agreement and it would includc a mechanism to adjust it semi-annually to reflect changes in the PFI's subsidiary loan rate. 4.21 Subloan Maturities. Depending on subproject requirements, the maturity for subioans granted to finance capital formation, such as investment in plant and equipment, would vary from 1 to 5 years. Working capital subloans would vary from 9 months to 18 months. 4.22 Environmental Requirements. A manual on environmental review procedures for individual subprojects will be prepared by the Government and reviewed by the Bank. It will become an annex of the CLRM. The manual will provide the guidelines to classify, from an environmental point of view, each sub-project to be financed by the credit line, allowing the development of a process under which local environmental laws and regulations will be applied by appropriate institutions i.e., environmental authorities and loan beneficiaries. Such a process will reduce the Bank's direct involvement in the implementation of a particular sub-project while still allowing it to carry out its supervisory function efficiently. The manual will be reviewed with the borrower prior to effectiveniess and it vill be approved as part of the CLRM. 4.23 Technical Assistance for Financial Intermediaries and Support for TU. Support to financial intermediaries would be critical for the success of the credit line and for the implementation of badly needed restructuring and overhauling of the banking system. Technical assistance requirements under the financial sector strengthening component would comprise the following subcomponents: (a) staffing of the TU with two experts in western-style banking for a period of two years each and start-up and incremental recurring costs required for the operation of the TU (US$1.6 million); (b) consulting services to implement a two-year technical assistance program to support the credit line-related lending activities of PFI and the development of western banking practices in the banking industry in general (US$0.4 million); (c) two years of consulting services by western experts who would do in-house work on developing SMEs' lending skills in selected PFIs participating in the SME window of the credit line (US$1 million); and (d) technical assistance to be provided by foreign consultants plus start-up and operational costs for the establishment of the BRU at the NBM (US$1 million). Efforts were made to finance as much as possible of the US$4 million estimated to be required for this subcomponent with foreign grant funding. During project preparation US$3.1 million was mobilized from the donors, the NBU agreed to support the incremental operating costs of the TU with US$0.5 million, while US$0.4 million is budgeted as a part of the loan to the Republic. Grants and Bank resources would be channeled through the PIU to the TU, BSD and BRU at the NBM. The costs associated with this subcomponent would be assumed entirely by the Republic. The NBM would manage this technical assistance program and act as fiscal agent of the Government. 4.24 Strengthening of NBM and Payments, Clearing and Settlement System. Under this component US$2.23 million would be used to cover expenditures associated with the purchasing of 37
 computer equipment, its installation (hardware and software), associated start-up costs and training of local staff. The executing agency for this subcomponent will be the NBM, which will use US$2.23 million in the implementation of its own information system (US$1.55 million) and the upgrading of the banks' Payments, Clearing and Settlement System (US$0.68 million), which operates under the umbrella of the NBM. A modernized, well-functioning tax system is an essential element in achieving macroeconomic stabilization, developing a clear set of the "rules of the game" needed for a market economy, and in facilitating the business investment needed in Moldova. The Government is committed to this process through a comprehensive review and reform of the tax system. The result will be a system which is simpler to cope with, fairer and competitive with its trading partners. In response to advice and recommendations from the IMF and the World Bank, and with the assistance of USAID-financed long-term resident technical advisers, the Ministry of Finance is undertaking three major initiatives that will: * Reform the structure of the tax laws in Moldova, e Restructure the tax administration, and * Computerize many of the functions of the Tax Inspectorate. Reform of tax policy mechanisms will create a broadly-based tax structure with low rates, giving investors a secure framework in which to work. Reform of the tax administration processes and procedures will help in clarifying rights and obligations, and will enable business to comply more easily and at lower administrative cost with the tax system. Finally, computerization of the Tax Inspectorate will allow business to devote a smaller share of their time and expenses to the tax collection process and for the Government to improve the efficiency of the administration. Overview of the current tax system To ensure financial stability for the government, the tax system in Moldova should raise the necessary revenues to finance government programs and services and service public debt, while reducing its reliance on credit. The system is far from meeting these objectives at present. Currently the situation is as follows: * Nominal GDP in Moldova was 7.8 bn lei in 1994, and is expected to increase to 8.65 bn lei (I 1 per cent) in 1995. * Government revenues were 1,317 m lei in 1994. The tax burden must be and remain competitive with its trading partners -- both in the former Soviet Union and in other countries. Recent developments In this context, the Government has already taken a number of steps to improve the tax system and improve the economic climate: * Business income tax rates have been significantly reduced, from 50 per cent (70 per cent for certain corporations) to 32 per cent; * A new income tax law for banks has been prepared and has passed first reading in Parliament and is expected to be enacted in a few weeks. This law will significantly improve the tax system for banks
 ANNEX E Page 3 of 11 by gradually reducing the tax rate from 40 per cent to 32 per cent and introducing a deductible reserve provision for loan losses (in line with agreements under the Structural Adjustment Loan). * New proposals are being developed to modernize the real estate tax law and the resource sector tax laws. * A new consolidated tax code is in preparation which will combine the existing set of income tax laws (currently over 15). * The system will be made simpler to cope with. For example, the current method for depreciation calculation is being reviewed and simplified. * Rather than requiring a separate amortization schedule for each good, a declining balance method with five categories of depreciation rate is being considered. * The method for determining allowable business expenses and the accounting method are also being reviewed with the aim of harmonizing them with market economy norms. * A discussion paper is in preparation that will explain the main objectives that the Government intends to follow with tax reform, present the major issues that it is considering, and outline next steps. The Government has also begun taking steps to modernize the tax administration: 4. Tax Administration Objectives Tax administration is currently very labor intensive and imposes substantial costs of compliance on business. Therefore, a process has already begun to consolidate its structure, modernize its facilities and computerize its facilities, improve the quality of the human resources working in the Tax Inspectorate, and improve compliance and collection techniques. * Various provisions have been introduced to improve the effectiveness of the Tax Inspectorate; * A new Chief of the Tax Inspectorate has been appointed and three senior positions have been created which will permit senior officials of the Tax Administration to plan and structure the new administration. Further steps are under way to improve tax administration: * The tax filing requirement is being reviewed in order to reduce and simplify the number of forms and amount of data required. * The tax filer identification system is being updated to be consistent with computer processing requirements. * The auditing of returns is being specialized. Currently, auditors have no specialization. They must deal with all types of tax and they are required to review each tax return every two years. In future, audit criteria will be changed to target cases where there is a high probability of evasion or fraud.
 ANNEX E Page 4 of I1 The Tax Inspectorate is improving its communication capacities with the business community to discuss and inform them of proposed changes and to better explain changes that have been adopted. (A newsletter was recently issued). 5. Computerization Objectives To ensure that the fiscal reform project is successful, modernization of the current computer hardware and software is essential. With the shift from a small number of taxpayers under central planning to a decentralized economy covering a much large number of enterprises and individuals responsible for their own tax returns, the quantity of transactions to be processed will soon become unmanageable through existing means. Without the aid of a well designed and well integrated automated data processing system, the Tax Inspectorate will not be able to fulfill its responsibilities effectively. This system will also serve to lessen the administrative burden the business community faces when it deals with the tax system. To develop and implement this plan, a software information engineering group that will concentrate their efforts on designing and implementing systems that will change the current way of doing business. This group will work closely with the advisors and key users to develop computer applications for the Tax Inspectorate. The Tax Inspectorate has already begun identifying the personnel that will be part of this group. In designing and implementing a computerized tax system, a number of goals will be pursued: I. Simplify data entry by using electronic information transfer as much as possible between computers within the Tax Inspectorate and from other external sources (banks, Customs, etc.) 2. Generate benefits to the Tax Inspectorate quickly, even if many parts of the system remain to be completed. Careful planning and phasing in of essential components at intervals throughout the development process will allow parts of the system to be successfully implemented in production prior to its completion. 3. Create a set of inter-networked, distributed computers, working in the framework of a comprehensive systems design, that will continue to provide benefits as further expansion of the system continues. 4. Provide taxpayer service on tax information. 5. Generate taxpayer identification numbers (TIN) for a broad base of taxpayers. 6. Centralize control of taxpayers for auditing and tax evasion purposes. 7. Maintain a central data base for taxpayers. 6. Organization of the Tax Inspectorate There are presently 39 local Tax Inspectorate offices in Moldova. The capital, Chisanau, contains the largest office as well as 5 district offices. The other local Tax Inspectorate offices are scattered throughout the country. All heads of the local Tax Inspectorate office report directly to the Chief of the
 ANNEX E Page 5 of 11 Tax Inspectorate. The local offices employ 1800 tax inspectors, of whom a minimal number have computer expertise. Currently, each local office is responsible for administering every tax base in their district. This includes processing, verification and collection of VAT, corporate income tax, personal income tax for self- employed, withholding tax for employees and the real estate and land tax. 7. Computerization of the Tax Inspectorate Volume of information processed To assess the machinery required for computerization, it is necessary to calculate the volume of information to be processed. The volume of data the Tax Inspectorate is currently processing is estimated by multiplying the number of taxpayers by the number of blanks required to be completed on each tax form. Adding up all the taxpayers for each different tax base gives a figure of 2 million tax records in Moldova. The amount of information required from the taxpayers can be expressed as about 50 million fields, or 150 megabytes of information. At present, the great majority of taxpayers are existing enterprises. With the introduction of a broad- based income tax on employees, and the inclusion of new businesses in the tax net, the number of tax records is expected to rise to 6 million by 1997. This and other changes will result in the volume of fields processed by the Tax Inspectorate to increase by a factor of 10, to about 500 million fields. Storage of this information will require about 1.5 gigabytes of computer space. The number of taxpayers now and in 1997 along with the amount of space required to store the tax filer information is available in Table 1. The taxpayer number identification system will also generate a large volume of data to be processed and stored. Currently there are 50,000 filers in the system, requiring 2 megabytes of storage space. This will expand to 3 million filers in 1997, requiring 200 megabytes of storage space. Current state of computerization Computerization of the Tax Inspectorate is in its infancy. The bulk of the hardware is in the capital, Chisinau, with the remainder scattered around the country. Each of the 39 local Tax Inspectorate offices is currently equipped with at least one 486 chip desktop computer, in addition to an older 286 machine. There are a total of 134 machines operating around the country. Of these, 47 are 486 machines, 24 are 386 machines and the remainder 286 machines or older. A detailed list of the computers currently available to the Tax Inspectorate appears in Table 2. The machines are not being used to their full capacity at the moment. Only the computers in the Chisinau district (the main Chisinau site and 5 other offices in tota!) are linked in a network and transmit information via modem. There are plans to create a network in other offices, but these have not been implemented as of now. Also, many of the existing machines are obsolete. Given the need for development of a standard software platform (Windows based), the existing 286 machines (and some XT/8088s) will not be able to be used in the future as part of a large, integrated network. Furthermore, the 386 machines will need to be upgraded to meet the minimum needs of the new system.
 ANNEX E Page 6 of 11 The functions these machines are providing is also linmited at the moment. The assignment of Taxpayer Identification Numbers (TIN) is done by computer. However, because there are no communications links between offices, this means that the TIN registration form is handed over to a local Tax Inspectorate office, then delivered to the Computer Center at the Ministry of Finance for processing. Then a certificate is returned back to the local office and the taxpayer. The treasury function in the Tax Inspectorate is computerized to a limited extent. Taxpayers go to their assigned bank and make a payment to a prespecified account set up by the Treasury specifically to handle taxpayer payments. The bank sends a paper report to the Tax Inspectorate each month listing the payments received. The Tax Inspectorate then uses this information to check that the amount that has been paid is equal to the amount it has calculated as the liability. The only tax bases this process applies to are the corporate income tax and the value added tax. There are no treasury functions computerized for the employee withholding system, the self-employed income tax, or the land or real estate tax. Presently, the only local Tax Inspectorate office with the ability to communicate electronically with the central site is in Belti. Once again, this only applies to tax payment records, not processing or report generating or other functions. No other electronic transfer of information is possible between offices outside of the capital and the Computer Center or the Central Tax Inspectorate. All document tracking, analysis and report generation is currently done by hand in the local offices and then sent to the Central Tax Inspectorate as needed. Tax processing for each tax is still done by hand in each Tax Inspectorate office. Corporate taxpayers are required to submit a balance sheet and income statement along with their statement of tax liability. The Tax Inspectorate checks the calculations by hand for each tax return and notifies the taxpayer in case of a discrepancy. Tax processing by hand is also done for the other major taxes: personal income tax (self-employed as well as employee withholding) or the land and property taxes. In addition, property valuation for buildings is done manually by the Biurtau of Technical Inventory (BTI). Valuation for land is done by the Ministry of Agriculture. Currently, thev are partly computerized, having available only obsolete equipment. This is a serious impediment to maintaining up-to-date, accurate values. The valuation process should be updated to utilize modern methods of valuation, mass appraisal, spatial analysis, and increasingly, market information. With the computerization of the Tax Inspectorate, Moldova will be modernizing its tax system. This will mean that document tracking, processing, verification, collection, transfer of information are all done on computer. Report generation and an on-line information system will allow the government to monitor its finances and conduct tax policy with much greater efficiency than ever before.
 ANNEX E Page 7 of I 1 8. Design and Implementation Schedule Four phases of implementation The computerization program is divided into four phases. Phase One, May 1995 to January 1996, is being devoted to the creating the underlying infrastructure of the system and the development of prototypes. During this phase, the new, simplified forms and procedures will be designed, and the systems development team will be writing the software to be used for tax calculation, document tracking, record keeping, and report generation for each tax base. Using a small sample of taxpayers, they will test this system, making changes if needed based on input received from the users (the Tax Inspectorate), the tax advisers and the taxpayers. Specialized software for property valuation will be installed. This will be done either at a central cite or at multiple locations. This policy decision and administrative arrangement has not yet been made by the government. This software will be used to collect, maintain and manage market data and conduct highly technical research of the real estate and land tax bases. The data and research will enable a much more accurate valuation of property. Use of valuation standards approximating market values will facilitate collection of required taxes. Computerization of valuation will allow up-to-date, accurate property values to be maintained in the system as the market economy continues to evolve. The resulting property tax system will be much fairer and socially equitable than before, and will have the potential of generating high levels of revenue. The resident advisers are supplying the Tax Inspectorate with a Pentium style server computer to be used as the hub of the systems design efforts. In addition, the Tax Inspectorate has seven 486 desktop machines allocated to the systems design team. Phase Two, from January through June 1996, is the beginning of the implementation of the system at the central site in Chisinau. The prototypes will be expanded into a full scale system using real data. The Value Added Tax will be the first tax base to be computerized. It is an ideal candidate since the VAT is one of the largest tax bases, and will be the easiest to computerize. During this phase, real data will be collected from VAT payments. The system will be used to calculate liabilities, monitor payments, and general reports. The aim is to continue testing the system using real data for one tax, then spread the system throughout Moldova by region and by tax base. At this time, the centralized database, containing complete information on all taxpayers, will be created. It will be maintained at the Computer Center in Chisinau. Communication links will be established with each of the nine regional Tax Inspectorate offices. External sources (i.e. Treasury, National Bank, commercial Banks, Customs, Financial Guard) will be able to send information to the Tax Inspectorate electronically, greatly increasing compliance capabilities. The Central Tax Inspectorate computer system will also be linked to this central system. Phase Three will last from July 1996 through the erd of the year. The new system design will be installed in a small number of satellite regions. Each of these will be linked electronically with the Central Tax Inspectorate. The excise tax and income tax are planned to be computerized during this time as weil. At this point, the broad based income tax system will be introduced, replacing the current employee withholding system. The Central Tax Inspectorate will have the capacity to retrieve information about the tax system in a much more timely fashion than ever before.
 ANNEX E Page 8 of 11 The final phase, Phase Four, will be the implementation in the regional Tax Inspectorate offices throughout Moldova. This is expected to take another five months, from January through May 1997. Each of the nine regional offices will establish direct links with the central office. The remaining local Tax Inspectorate offices will be clustered into networks around the nine regional offices. The remaining tax bases, primarily the land and real estate taxes, are expected to be computerized during this stage. Following full implementation, the systems development team will become the Systems Design Center. Its function will be to continually adapt the computer system to the changing tax system in Moldova. This includes updating software as the tax code changes, maintaining a secure database of taxpayer information, and responding to information requests from the Tax Policy office within the Ministry of Finance. 9. Funds allocation The following table summarizes the plan for allocating the proceeds of the loan: Hardware $1,342,145 Software $ 400,000 Facilities $ 75,000 Contingencies $ 100,000 Total $1,917,145 Hardware At the heart of the system will be three extra powerful computer servers, equipped with a Pentium chip. Each will have a specialized function, and therefore a specialized configuration. The data base server will have an extra large (5 GB) hard drive. The returns processing server will have expanded (64 MB) memory and a large (2 GB) hard drive. The communications server will have a standard I GB hard drive. The Development team, the Taxpayer Identification Number center and the Chisinau territorial Tax Inspectorates will also have Pentium machines, though not as powerful as the previous ones. Each local Tax Inspectorate office will use a 486 machine as the center of its processing facility. All the machines will be linked into a two-stage network. Smaller local offices will communicate via modem with a nearby regional center. Each of the nine regional centers will, in turn, communicate with the central site in Chisinau. In essence, this will be one large, tenritory-wide network. This will enable the local offices to communicate more effectively with the central office by transmitting information electronically, rather than on paper. The Computer Center will be able to archive taxpayer records, and provide the Ministry of Finance with information it requires to do tax policy analysis. The Ministry, through the Central Tax Inspectorate office, will be able to quickly access information summarizing the tax collection activities of the local offices.
 ANNEX E Page 9 of 11 The land and property tax valuation system will require four dedicated computers to properly run the system. The research and valuation will be conducted from the central site, with the billing and collection functions performed by the local Tax Inspectorate offices. Taxpayers' payments will be made at local banks. The data entry process is the most labor-intensive one, but it requires the least sophisticated computer. The data typed in will automatically flow into a larger machine, either a central machine within a local Tax Inspectorate office, or to the date base server at the Computer Center. Therefore, these computers can be purchased without a hard drive and will function simply as a "dumb terminal". In addition, there will be approximately 50 other dumb terminals around the country for on-line access to information stored elsewhere. The remainder of the money spent on equipment will be devoted to printers, network cards, tape backup systems, power backup systems, and miscellaneous supplies. Details of the computer equipment configuration are listed in the appendix as Table 3. A summary of which offices will be receiving which type of equipment is contained as Table 4 in the Appendix. Several different types of software will need to be purchased for the computerization of the Tax Inspectorate and land valuation system. * Computer Aided Software Engineering (CASE) tool: This is a development tool for an analyst or programmer which will be used to assist in the design stages of the system. A multi-user license for 14 application developers will be installed in the LAN system. * Microsoft Project This is a tool for managing the development effort, which provides an automated capability to follow the progress of the project. Delays and / or deviations can be identified and corrected immediately. The use of this tool is essential for completing the project on time and within budget. * Novell Netware This will be the software used to run the computer network. Local users will be able to send and retrieve data and communicate with other local offices and the Data Processing center electronically. * Windows This is the operating system selected for the computerization plan. * Unix This is a multi-tasking software that permits several users to simultaneously access the central data base. * Microsoft Office This is a package of integrated, office automation software which includes: Word, Excel, Access and Powerpoint. Specialized software will be needed for the land and property valuation system. This system will provide an integrated valuation environment that supports the major approaches to market value
 ANNEX E Page I0oflI estimation. The valuation subsystem will allow for generation of values by the income approach for income producing properties (including properties where imputed rent can be applied), cost approach for land and/or buildings and the comparables approach for land and/or buildings. The system will also support the adaptive estimation procedure as well as multiple regression analysis and descriptive statistics. The system will provide basic data maintenance and report generation. The spatial analysis subsystem will support automated mapping, including land value maps, multiple layers of spatial and attribute records, polygon buffering and overlays, and land suitability analysis. The system will allow data porting from one subsystem to another as well as to generic software such as spreadsheets and word processors. Facilities The Ministry of Finance has committed space to the Application Development team. This will be in a site apart from the Central Tax Inspectorate. The 14 person team will work here temporarily until a new building! for the Tax Inspectorate is completed. This temporary space will need office firniture, wall partitions, wiring for a local area network (LAN) and telephone lines. A conference room and secure data s-w-ge will also be provided. The central tax data base will be located in the new Tax Inspectorate building. Facilities for data storage and offices for the development team have been taken into consideration during the planning stage for this building. Nine regional sites have been selected to provide connectivity to the central system. Extra telephone lines will be provided at the sites for the modems which will be used to transmit and receive data. In the five Chisinau Tax Inspectorate district offices and the regional offices, terminals will be installed to provide tax filer services, such as document and payment tracking. 10. Development and training Through a technical assistance project in Moldova, USAID is funding several aspects of the modernization of the Moldovan Tax Inspectorate. The primary measure of assistance has been the financing of KPMG Barents Group advisers, including a full-time Computerization Adviser who will work on the project for a period of two years. He will be supported as required by short-term advisers in areas such as database design, network administration and computer-aided software engineering. He has been working closely with the Tax Inspectorate to evaluate the current state of computerization and draw up a plan for computerization. During the next two years, he will be overseeing the implementation of the computerization plan. Development The Tax Inspectorate has committed to putting together an Application Development team. Over the course of the two year project, this team will work in consultation with the Computerization Adviser and the system users to design and implement the system. The Application Development team will consist of the following: * Local hires by the Tax Inspectorate I Database Administrator I Network Specialist
 ANNEX E Page 11 of 11 I Computer Assisted Systems Engineering (CASE) tool specialist I Analyst / Programmers 4 Programmers * Transfers from the Computer Center 4 Analyst / Programmers (Taxpayer Identification Number system) Training Training will proceed in several stages: * First, the Applications Development team will be trained using specialized software for system design and management such as CASE tool and Microsoft Project. They will also be trained in using office automation software (Microsoft Office), networking software (Novell Netware) and database management software (Unix). * As the system spreads throughout Moldova, users of the system will receive training in the applications developed, on-line communications, information retrieval and office automation software, as needed. Both classroom style and on-the-job training will be utilized. In addition, customized courses will be offered by short-term advisors on specific topics.

doc.repnme: Moldova - First Private Sector Development Project
doc.abstracts: The principal objective of the First Private Sector Development Project is to support and help accelerate the government reform program in the enterprise and financial sectors, focusing especially on measures enhancing the links between commercial banks and enterprises. In particular, the project will: 1) accelerate the emergence and growth of small and medium scale enterprises (SMEs); 2) streamline larger enterprises and release currently unproductive assets into the market, thus creating smaller, focused companies; 3) increase the efficiency of resource mobilization and credit allocation through the provision of assistance to restructure the banking system; and 4) strengthen the infrastructure for banking activity, and provide institutional development support for solvent banks. The project will comprise two components: 1) an enterprise sector strengthening component (ESSC); and 2) a financial sector strengthening component (FSSC). The ESSC will facilitate the growth of a population of viable and competitive enterprises by providing technical assistance for rationalizing selected larger enterprises and by providing private SMEs with the technical assistance necessary to prepare bankable investment projects. The ESSC will also provide computer hardware and software to assist in strengthening the ability of the tax administration within the Ministry of Finance to collect taxes in a timely fashion and lower transaction costs. The FSSC will provide resources -a credit line- through qualified participating banks, for medium-term loans to private and privatized enterprises. This component will also: 1) assist with the development of banking skills in the participating banks; 2) strengthen the payments system through the provision of computer software and hardware for the clearing center at the National Bank of Moldova (NBM); and 3) support further institutional development -including automation- for NBM as a whole.
